title: 107_s1315
content: The Act may be cited as the "Judicial Improvement and Integrity Act of 2001" and includes increasing penalties for using physical force to tamper with witnesses, victims, or informants. The "Judicial Improvement and Integrity Act of 2001" amends Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code, to increase penalties for using physical force or threats to influence or prevent testimony in official proceedings. The "Judicial Improvement and Integrity Act of 2001" amends Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code, to increase penalties for obstructing official proceedings or hindering communication of information to law enforcement. The "Judicial Improvement and Integrity Act of 2001" enhances penalties for obstructing official proceedings or hindering communication of information to law enforcement, including increased imprisonment terms for specific offenses such as attempted murder or use of physical force against any person. The "Judicial Improvement and Integrity Act of 2001" increases penalties for obstructing official proceedings and retaliating against witnesses by imposing the same penalties for conspiracy to commit these offenses. Amendments are made to sections 1512 and 1513 of title 18, United States Code to align with these changes. Amendments to title 18, United States Code include inserting "supervised release" after "probation" in subsections (a)(1)(B) and (b)(2). SEC. 3 amends Title 18 of the United States Code to allow for the imposition of both a fine and imprisonment in certain sections. SEC. 4 addresses the reinstatement of counts dismissed through a plea agreement. Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new section, "Sec. 3296. Counts dismissed pursuant to a plea agreement." This section outlines the conditions under which dismissed counts can be reinstated by the District Court, including the original filing within the limitations period, dismissal through an approved plea agreement, vacating of guilty plea, and a motion by the United States within 60 days of vacating the plea. The District Court can consider defenses or objections, other than statute of limitations, to reinstated counts. Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new section for dismissed counts under a plea agreement. SEC. 5. Appeals from certain dismissals are clarified in Section 3731 of title 18, United States Code by allowing appeals on any part of dismissed counts. SEC. 6. Supervised release terms in controlled substance cases are clarified. SEC. 7 amends penalties for drug abuse and import/export, allowing courts to impose probation or supervised release when reducing imprisonment sentences in certain cases. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow for the imposition of probation or supervised release when reducing imprisonment sentences. Additionally, section 3583 of title 18 is clarified to include making restitution as a proper condition of supervised release.
